thread.title: Valencia football opens league with blowout win over Golden Valley
thread.title_full: Valencia football opens league with blowout win over Golden Valley

author: Dan Agnew
title: Valencia football opens league with blowout win over Golden Valley
text:
Valencia football opens league with blowout win over Golden Valley Vikings dominate as they shut out Grizzlies Posted: October 9, 2015 11:23   9, 2015 11:23 p.m. Valencia middle linebacker Jordan Grisaffi, 22, takes down Golden Valley quarterback Victor Corona, 2, as fellow Viking defensive end Tayler Manuel, 35, rushes in to assist during both teams’ Foothill League opener at Valencia High School on Friday. Signal photo by Katharine Lotze. 
Just winning wasn’t going to be good enough for this Valencia football team. 
In it’s Foothill League opener against Golden Valley, the Vikings needed to demonstrate their dominance. 
And that they did, particularly on the defensive end in a 37-0 victory over the Grizzlies on Friday night at Valencia High School. 
“We needed to show that we’re still the six-time defending champions of this league, so it was a statement win,” said Valencia linebacker Tariq Speights, who had one of Valencia’s nine sacks on the evening. 
Coming off its best start to the season in program history, Golden Valley (4-2 overall, 0-1 Foothill League) was stifled by the Vikings’ relentless pass rush and disciplined coverage. 
The Grizzlies were held to 38 yards of total offense, and never threatened to score in the game. Six of Golden Valley’s drives ended in three-and-outs, and two ended with turnovers. 
In addition to Speights, Valencia routinely brought pressure with its two returning All-Santa Clarita Valley defensive ends, Jermaine Brown and Tayler Manuel. 
“It’s a team loss here. Offensively we put our defense in some tough spots,” said Golden Valley head coach Dan Kelley. 
In the first half, it was pretty much all defense for both teams. Valencia cashed in a Victor Corona interception with an Effie Davalos 3-yard touchdown run to take a 7-0 lead midway through the first quarter. 
Later in the first, a Grizzlies’ muffed punt helped set up Kevin Neitzke 30-yard field goal to extend the lead to 10-0. 
Neitzke nailed three kicks in the game, also adding a 29-yarder later in the first half and a 39-yarder in the second half. 
Valencia held a 13-0 advantage at the break, unable to get much going offensively against an also-stout Golden Valley defense. 
“They were still right there in the game. We didn’t separate ourselves enough,” said Valencia head coach Larry Muir. “In the second half, I was proud of our guys. We stepped it up and played a little faster, a little tougher, a little smarter.” 
The game was effectively put away in the third quarter when Vikings quarterback Cole Parkinson found Drew Rivello open for a 54-yard pass to the end zone. That made it a 23-0 lead, and it jumped to 30-0 a few minutes later when Parkinson found Tim Wiggins for another scoring pass. 
After nursing an injury earlier in the week, backup Aaron Thomas started the game under center for the Vikings but only played the opening series. 
Parkinson completed 14-of-20 passes for 175 yards and the two scores. Valencia’s Jahmar Berkley was the game’s leading rusher with 62 yards on 11 carries, the final of which was a 34-yard touchdown early in the fourth quarter to set the final score.
